snippet: Could a federal judge’s admirable candor about making a mistake on a decision have an effect on whether such laws will continue to be upheld?
abstract: Editorial admires Federal Judge Richard Posner's admission that he had failed to appreciate how voter-ID laws would be abused when he wrote the 2005 decision upholding Indiana's statute, one of country's first voter-ID law; questions what effect Posner's candor might have, in light of cases across the country dealing with litigation over ever-stricter versions of such laws.
lead_paragraph: Could a federal judge’s admirable candor about making a mistake on a decision have an effect on whether such laws will continue to be upheld?
